awd_abstract_narration:
This award supports the Midwest Representation Theory Conference, to be held March 11-13, 2022 at the University of Michigan. The conference will gather established experts, recent Ph.D.s, and graduate students to discuss and disseminate new results in the broad area of representation theory of local and adelic points of algebraic groups, a fundamental subject in mathematics, with many applications both inside and outside mathematics. The conference will be the latest in a sequence of conferences that have consistently provided a forum in which students and experts alike present and discuss state-of-the-art-work in the discipline.

The conference features invited talks from a diverse cohort of speakers, including several young researchers working in a broad range of topics, as well as contributed talks. Speakers' specialties range widely, with two broad themes being supercuspidal representations, and automorphic forms and L-functions. Supercuspidal representations are the fundamental building blocks of admissible representations of rational points of groups over local fields, and they typically appear as ramified local components of automorphic representations of adelic groups. These, along with their associated L-functions, are central objects of study in modern number theory. The conference website is https://homepage.divms.uiowa.edu/~mkrishna/2022mrtc/.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The 2022 Midwest Representation-Theory Conference was held March 11?13, 2022 in Ann Arbor, MI.  77 people participated, 13 of these attended virtually over Zoom.

There were four to five short (20-minute) talks each full day of the conference, and one or two long (50-minute) talks each day of the conference, for a total of eleven short talks and four long talks.  In accordance with our goal of furthering opportunities for early-career mathematicians, seven of the speakers were graduate students, and four had recently received their PhDs. There was a healthy mix of contributed and invited talks, with many of the contributed talks being delivered by younger participants.  The conference continued what we hope will be a tradition, inaugurated at the 2020 Midwest Representation-Theory Conference, in which at least one of the long talks was related to themes concerning diversity, equity, and inclusion.  At the 2020 Midwest Representation-Theory conference, which was completely virtual thanks to COVID-19, this talk was given by Phil Kuzko.  At the 2022 conference this talk was delivered by Professor David Goldberg, who spoke on the subject of the Math Alliance, a national mentoring community.

The conference provided ample opportunities and encouragement for networking, with special focus on the interface between early-career researchers and experienced researchers.
